description:
I haven‚Äôt posted in a while because I‚Äôve been on the road meeting with more large employers to understand what‚Äôs really happening in employee wellbeing today.

A consistent pattern has emerged from my conversations. Despite all the progress in this field, many leaders feel that wellbeing, as it‚Äôs currently delivered, just isn‚Äôt working anymore.

Here are the five biggest themes I‚Äôve heard:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Intrinsic, not extrinsic.
Employers are tired of paying people to participate. Incentives have become transactional; the same employees engage every year while the rest tune out. Leaders want to shift the focus from financial rewards to meaning by tapping into intrinsic motivation that makes wellbeing personal and lasting (and, of course, cheaper).

2Ô∏è‚É£ Consolidation, not fragmentation.
Most companies now manage 20‚Äì30 point solutions across mental health, fitness, nutrition, sleep, and more. None of them talk to each other. Employees are overwhelmed, HR is exhausted, and engagement is low. The next generation of wellbeing products needs to be integrated, multi-dimensional, and easy to access.

3Ô∏è‚É£ N of 1.
No more fixed, pre-designed journeys or one-size-fits-many ‚Äúpersonas.‚Äù Employers want to meet every employee where they are, every single day, so that wellbeing feels adaptive, contextual, and deeply personal. Every individual is unique, and they each need their own wellbeing program.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Truly global and culturally fluent.
Multinational employers are done with ‚ÄúAmerican wellbeing programs lost in translation.‚Äù They want experiences that understand local norms, languages, cultures, and values‚Äîsolutions that feel as authentic in Singapore or S√£o Paulo as they do in San Francisco.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Bottom-up, not top-down.
The old model of prescriptive, centrally managed programs is fading. Employers want to empower employees to design their own wellbeing paths, to set goals that matter to them, and to pursue those goals together with colleagues.

To me, AI feels purpose-built to solve for this employer wish list.

AI can understand the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind someone‚Äôs goal, break it into achievable steps, and provide intelligent, real-time, and adaptive guidance that taps into intrinsic motivation. It can connect fragmented tools into a unified, personalized experience. Because they‚Äôre learning from billions of users around the world every day, LLMs can make wellbeing truly global from day one. And perhaps most importantly, AI can bring people together. It can now facilitate group dynamics, shared accountability, and peer support at a scale we‚Äôve never seen before.

My new company, Goal AI, is building AI-native products that are responsive to these principles. We don‚Äôt have all the answers, but we do have a few visionary employers who are co-designing the future of employee wellbeing with us.

It‚Äôs an exciting time to be building at the intersection of AI and wellbeing, and I look forward to sharing more soon! | 32 comments on LinkedIn
